children.text: The existing code includes several steps like loading data, checking stationarity with ADF test, feature selection, fitting ARIMA and SARIMAX models, and an ANOVA test. The TODO comment is right after plotting the ARIMA diagnostics and before fitting the SARIMAX model. Looking at the code, after the ARIMA model diagnostics plots, the user probably needs to display those plots. In Python with matplotlib, after setting up the plots, you need to call plt.show() to actually render them. Otherwise, the plots might not appear or might be closed immediately, especially in non-interactive environments.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: The existing code uses plt.figure, creates subplots, and then has plt.tight_layout(). But there's no plt.show() after that. So the missing line is likely plt.show() to display the ARIMA diagnostics plots before moving on to fitting the SARIMAX model. Without this, the plots might not be shown properly. That's probably the line that's missing in the TODO section.
children.label: code_analysis

tree.original_reasoning:
Okay, let me see what the user is asking here. The task is to complete the Python code by filling in the missing parts. The existing code includes several steps like loading data, checking stationarity with ADF test, feature selection, fitting ARIMA and SARIMAX models, and an ANOVA test. The TODO comment is right after plotting the ARIMA diagnostics and before fitting the SARIMAX model.

Looking at the code, after the ARIMA model diagnostics plots, the user probably needs to display those plots. In Python with matplotlib, after setting up the plots, you need to call plt.show() to actually render them. Otherwise, the plots might not appear or might be closed immediately, especially in non-interactive environments.

The existing code uses plt.figure, creates subplots, and then has plt.tight_layout(). But there's no plt.show() after that. So the missing line is likely plt.show() to display the ARIMA diagnostics plots before moving on to fitting the SARIMAX model. Without this, the plots might not be shown properly. That's probably the line that's missing in the TODO section.
